raw_text:
Umaga ready for "fearsome" Lions
 
 All Blacks captain Tama Umaga has warned the British and Irish Lions will be his most fearsome opponents yet ahead of their summer tour.
 
 But Umaga, in England for Saturday's IRB Rugby Aid match, also backed New Zealand to win the three-Test series against the Lions. He told BBC Sport: "It's potentially the most fearsome line-up I've ever come up against. They're awesome. "But I'd back us all the way to beat them when they come over." Lions boss Sir Clive Woodward is set to announce his squad for the June-July tour next month.
 
 When Woodward was appointed last year, it was widely believed he would rely heavily on his former England players. But Umaga said: "He'd be hard pushed to do that now considering the shape of the Six Nations. "Don't get me wrong, England have got a lot of talented guys and I'm sure there are some of them who'll make the Lions Test XV. "But you can't disguise Wales and Ireland in particular. Some of the tries they've scored have been great. I'll admit it'll be fairly awesome lining up against the likes of Brian O'Driscoll."
 
 Umaga will meet O'Driscoll in Saturday's Rugby Aid match at Twickenham, with the Irish captain leading the Northern Hemisphere side. O'Driscoll is among a host of players in the Northern Hemisphere squad, coached by Woodward, that are tipped for Lions call-ups. "It'll be good for us to get an early idea of some of these guys, although a lot can change between now and June," Umaga said. The 31-year-old admitted interest in the Lions tour was immense, calling it "the biggest thing to hit New Zealand since Lord of the Rings". He added: "As players, it's enough for us to be driven by the rarity of playing the Lions. In fact, it's not just us All Blacks - it's the talk of the country."
 
 Umaga admitted the fear of injury weighed on his mind ahead of Saturday's charity game, which features a host of big names including George Gregan, Andrew Mehrtens and Chris Latham. But he admitted the value of the cause - proceeds of the match will go to aiding victims of the tsunami - easily won him over. "The second [Southern Hemisphere coach] Rod Macqueen made the approach, I didn't hesitate. It was great when New Zealand Rugby then gave me the all clear. "Thankfully I didn't know anyone that was involved in the tragedy of the tsunami but you couldn't miss all the horrific reports on the news. "There are so many people that were affected, are still affected and will be affected for a long time. It's just good to know we can do something minor to help out."
 
 - The match will be televised on BBC One at 1400 GMT on Saturday.
llama3.2:1b: Umaga backs Lions with All Blacks captain Tama Umaga warning the British and Irish Lions that he believes they are his most fearsome opponents yet, with a potential three-Test series against them in June-July. He also expresses interest in meeting Welsh player Brian O'Driscoll before the tour starts and says he is impressed by the shape of the Six Nations competition.
llama3.2:3b: All Blacks captain Tama Umaga warns the British and Irish Lions will be his most fearsome opponents yet, but believes New Zealand can win the three-Test series. He backs Sir Clive Woodward's team selection, citing Wales and Ireland's impressive Six Nations performances, including tries by Brian O'Driscoll.
gemma2:2b: Umaga believes the Lions will be the most formidable opponents in his career and that New Zealand is favored to win the upcoming series. He acknowledges the potential strength of the Lions squad but points out the strong performances from Welsh and Irish teams in the Six Nations.  He anticipates facing a challenging lineup including Brian O'Driscoll, and sees the Lions tour as a significant cultural event in New Zealand. The Rugby Aid match at Twickenham raises money for tsunami relief efforts.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tama Umaga says the British and Irish Lions will be his most fearsome opponents ahead of their summer tour in England. He backs New Zealand to win against the likes of Brian O'Driscoll, but suggests he'd back "us all" for a victory. Umaga will meet the British and Irish Lions' South American players at Twickenham on Saturday.
qwen2.5:1.5b: All Blacks captain Tama Umaga expects the British and Irish Lions to be his most formidable opponents in their upcoming tour, while Sir Clive Woodward's squad is being announced for the June-July tour next month. Umaga will meet Brian O'Driscoll during a charity match at Twickenham against Northern Hemisphere sides.
qwen2.5:3b: All Blacks captain Tama Umaga warned the British and Irish Lions would be his most fearsome opponents yet, despite backing New Zealand to win their summer series. Umaga expressed interest in the Lions tour but acknowledged potential injuries could affect player selection. He will play against Brian O'Driscoll in Saturday's IRB Rugby Aid match at Twickenham. While injury concerns initially led Umaga to hesitate about playing for the Lions, he supported the cause due to its humanitarian value in aiding tsunami victims.

tinyllama:1.1b: The British and Irish Lion's coach, Sir Clive Woodward, has announced his squad for the upcoming summer tour of New Zealand, and All Black captain Tamara Umaga has warned that the Lion's are "the most fearsome opponents yet" despite their impressive form during the Six Nations. However, Umaga believes the value of the cause outweighs the potential harm of injury, as he is set to play against the Northern Hemispheire side coached by All Blacks head coach Rod Macqueen. The match will be held on Satuday and will be televised on BBC One at 1400 GMT.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The All Blacks captain Tama Umaga has shared his excitement for the upcoming tour of England against the British and Irish Lions, who pose a fearsome lineup to the All Blacks. The two sides have faced each other 21 times with the All Blacks winning 13 of those matches. This will be their first meeting in 17 years since the 2002 tour, which was dominated by New Zealand's World Cup-winning captain David Kirshner and his side. Despite this, Umaga believes that the Lions are the most fearsome opponents they have ever faced. The All Blacks' head coach, Sir Clive Woodward, is expected to reveal his squad for the upcoming tour next month.

Umaga will meet Brian O'Driscoll in Saturday's Rugby Aid match at Twickenham. They both agree it'll be good for them to get an early idea of some of these guys. Umaga admits interest in the Lions tour is immense and they're the talk of the country. As players, it's enough for us to be driven by the rarity of playing the Lions. It's not just us All Blacks but the whole country talks about it. The charity game will go to aid tsunami victims, which easily won Umaga over. He admits the fear of injury weighs on his mind ahead of the match, but he couldn't miss the opportunity to do something for those affected by the tragedy.
